For an average editor, it is not possible or safe to manually remove the __NOINDEX__ tag from a newly created Wikipedia article. The tag is part of a deliberate system to ensure quality control, and attempts to bypass this process are likely to be reverted and may lead to disciplinary action. ðŸ”—

Why manual removal is not possible or safe

â€¢ System-enforced: Wikipedia automatically adds the __NOINDEX__ tag to all new mainspace articles. It is not a simple template that can be deleted. While the tag can be technically edited, the system overrides any non-compliant changes.

â€¢ Permissions required: Only experienced volunteer editors with "new page reviewer" permissions can manually remove the tag before the automated 90-day period ends. This is a trusted role within the community.

â€¢ Discourages spam: The primary purpose of the waiting period is to discourage "spammy" or low-quality content from quickly getting high search rankings.

key_points.details: Wikipedia automatically adds the tag to new mainspace articles. The system overrides manual edits to remove it.
Only 'new page reviewers' can remove the tag before the automated 90-day period ends.
The waiting period prevents low-quality or spam content from immediately achieving high search engine rankings.
Attempting to circumvent the process is seen as a 'red flag' and can lead to article deletion or disciplinary action.
